stream_context.summary: Kaze did live level-building on the still-unnamed papercraft ‘Yoshi’s Island’ overworld, refining mechanics (mainly the Spin Jump) and designing new props, enemies and Yoshi-Coin set-ups.

development_findings.summary: The Spin Jump was nerfed: lower initial lift, added A-button mashing for height, reduced air-turning; goal is to make it a safety tool not a sequence-breaker.
development_findings.quote: The spin jump is cool, but it's way too strong.

development_findings.summary: After tests Kaze is leaning toward keeping the current Spin Jump tuning but remains open to further tweaks (e.g., stall without height gain).
Level geometry progress: full castle added, new starting area layout, first Egypt-style section with tilting cardboard platforms, improved Styrofoam mountains.
A camera-space pseudo-normal/specular system was implemented to give Styrofoam and metal props convincing shine on N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: You see how when I turn the camera, the brightness of the pixel changes … that’s what I’m doing.

development_findings.summary: Collectible planning: needs five Yoshi Coins; ideas include trampoline coin near spawn, secret cardboard flap tunnel, coin atop pyramid, Bowser cut-out mini-bridge fight, Peach rescue from Shy Guys, Bob-omb-opened cannon.
Enemy/NPC concepts must pre-date the N64 era; scissor enemy rejected, Shy Guys approved, Bowser and Pink Bob-omb proposed, paper doodles (Peach, Luigi, Toad, Yoshi) already exist.
development_findings.quote: We’re not referencing anything Nintendo made after 1996 or after 2001, whenever the last N64 game released.

development_findings.summary: Created a new ‘Thimble Shy Guy’: metal thimble body with eyes/mask and brown feet; Kaze built model, custom metal bump/spec texture and kept it low-poly for N64.
development_findings.quote: What if we use one of those with like eyes drawn on? That would be perfect for a Shy Guy.

development_findings.summary: Viewer-submitted 69-triangle cotton cloud model likely to replace Kaze’s original 45-triangle version for better look.
Performance tests: un-optimised 8 k-polygon level (88 k with text) already runs 60 fps on emulator, 30 fps on real N64; vertex colouring and further reduction planned.
High-level scope: 15 main courses are planned; game and source will be released for free, with possible cosmetic DLC only if legally allowed.
development_findings.quote: Yes, the source will be public. … I never charge for my games. I wouldn’t be allowed to.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design philosophy is to give players ‘security’ options without trivialising level design; he refuses to tailor mechanics solely for advanced exploits.
context_findings.quote: I’m not making changes specifically just so you can back-amuse.

context_findings.summary: He consciously avoids post-N64 references to stay historically respectful and minimise legal risk.
First encounter with a persistent ‘hater’ disliking every video amused rather than discouraged him.
context_findings.quote: I have also taken notes that I think we have our first real hater … this is exciting.

context_findings.summary: Shows perfectionist tendencies: spends time on small aesthetic details (e.g., aquarium bubbles chasing each other).
Open, crowdsourced workflow: actively prototypes on stream, takes fan suggestions but asserts final decision authority.

biobak.summary: Replaced placeholder textures that showed post-N64 enemies, keeping art era-appropriate.
Reportedly ‘almost done’ with an unnamed asset (context suggests course graphics).

badub.summary: Will compose adaptive music that changes between the level’s biomes; current stream used Paper Mario placeholders.

zeina.summary: Responsible for drawing new cloud assets; suggested cotton-ball and hand-drawn cloud styles.

key_stories.title: Taming the Spin Jump
key_stories.summary: Kaze realised the new Spin Jump let players scale walls and bypass challenges. He iteratively cut its vertical speed, added mash-based height, and limited air control while live-testing.
key_stories.process: Adjusted physics constants on stream, compared feel against existing stages, and gauged chat feedback.
key_stories.outcome: Current build offers stall/safety without excessive height; Kaze ‘kind of likes’ the new feel but may revisit.
key_stories.key_quote: Maybe I don’t need to edit the spin jump; maybe this is fine.

key_stories.title: Inventing the Thimble Shy Guy
key_stories.summary: Needing Shy Guys that fit the craft theme, Kaze brainstormed materials, rejected cups and scissors, and settled on sewing thimbles. He built a low-poly model, experimented with UVs and a pseudo-metallic shader to convey bumps.
key_stories.challenge: Design an enemy that reads as a Shy Guy yet uses real-world craft materials and runs on N64 limits.
key_stories.process: Live modelling, texture sourcing, tweaking specular math, community feedback, polygon trimming.
key_stories.outcome: Prototype Thimble Shy Guy approved for placement as Peach’s harasser in the paper level.
key_stories.key_quote: What if we use one of those with like eyes drawn on? That would be perfect for a Shy Guy.
